@chrisalbon Still, I've been referred to as "Mr" when teaching. It's not the end of the world, but it's academia... really? I can only imagine how much worse it is for women. 2/2

@chrisalbon I've read so many stories of men on a panel referred to as "Dr" and the women referred to by first name. I don't get it. It's so intentional. I couldn't see myself ever accidentally doing it. I only go by "Dr." when teaching. 1/2

DeepVariant 1.0, the latest release of an open-source tool for isolating genome variants from sequencing data, significantly reduces sequencing errors to achieve Best Overall accuracy in 3 categories of the @PrecisionFDA v2 Truth Challenge. Read more ‚Üì https://t.co/JaxpgxUoRj

We are committed to helping researchers spend more of their time understanding #COVID19 instead of wrangling data, while keeping user privacy and security at the forefront. https://t.co/urevEjDvGg https://t.co/BNEPLhPwLM

RigL is a new algorithm for training sparse neural networks. Instead of pruning a pre-existing dense network, it dynamically builds one during training without sacrificing accuracy relative to traditional approaches. Learn how it‚Äôs done at https://t.co/VZa1Ve9uH1 https://t.co/smxQZ7A05w

Introducing an #ImitationLearning approach for the low-data regime that calculates the Wasserstein distance (aka the earth mover‚Äôs distance) between expert and agent, yielding excellent performance with limited demonstrations or environment interaction. https://t.co/QbaQ7mTI5M https://t.co/hShNL73KWO

Today we present the technology behind our recently expanded flood forecasting system, which includes new morphological inundation models and alert-targeting models, plus a look at our next generation water level model, HydroNets. Read more at https://t.co/RZSiO5MfNU https://t.co/ejH6SrLvqK

Introducing KeyPose, a new #ComputerVision model that estimates 3D keypoints of transparent objects from monocular or stereo images without explicitly computing depth, demonstrating state-of-the-art results for depth estimation. Learn all about it at https://t.co/ZaTYFhaTkO https://t.co/XtBsLNPveC

We are proud to partner with @NSF, a leader in advancing science & technology, to support a National AI Research Institute focused on Human-AI Interaction and Collaboration. To learn more and find the NSF solicitation, visit our post on the Keyword at ‚Üì https://t.co/a0iezmsnSR

Announcing C2D2, a #MachineLearning-based approach to improving colonoscopy screening coverage that performs real-time local 3D reconstruction of the colon during the procedure, and identifies regions outside the field of view of the endoscope. Read more ‚Üìhttps://t.co/U3nonNBkxt

In ‚ÄúHartree-Fock on a Superconducting Qubit Quantum Computer‚Äù, appearing today in @ScienceMagazine, the Google AI Quantum team highlights details behind the largest chemical simulation performed on a quantum computer to date. Axial-DeepLab is a novel network for image segmentation that enables long-range attention by replacing all convolution layers with sequential 1D height and width self-attention modules, resulting in state-of-the-art performance. Learn more below: https://t.co/N1h9U319Wy

A new study of the >31M datasets cataloged by #DatasetSearch analyzes their accessibility and usability, makes recommendations for dataset publishers, and includes a metadata dataset release to encourage additional research. Read more and get the data ‚Üì https://t.co/XSIZrDlxwn

To address the challenges unique to offline #ReinforcementLearning, we are releasing an open-source benchmark, D4RL, as well as a simple and effective offline RL algorithm, called conservative Q-learning (CQL). Read all about it at https://t.co/m7SBh78UrP https://t.co/rKhRJfC1TW

Introducing LaBSE, a multilingual BERT model for the generation of cross-lingual sentence embeddings that exhibits exceptional performance for both high- and low-resource languages. Learn more, including how to get the pre-trained model, at https://t.co/dw6DHc8ZBz

Sweet because: These are signs that NeurIPS is maturing. @_KarenHao wrote an article about the community growing up: https://t.co/27QvaQQkB8 We‚Äôre getting better at diversity/inclusion and taking responsibility for our actions, though there‚Äôs still room to grow.

Bayesian methods and causality got a lot of buzz. I was excited about progress in self-supervised learning, while others were excited about federated learning, or using DL to predict biological sequences. Fascinating areas, but the AI community no longer marches in one direction.
The community has grown so much that we no longer coalesce around a small handful of ideas. People now specialize more in verticals, and I felt less of the ‚Äúcore‚Äù coming together, which I miss.
Reflecting on #NeurIPS2019. Great meeting as usual, but the AI community is maturing, which felt bittersweet. Bitter because:

Courses 1 & 2 of @deeplearningai_‚Äòs newest Specialization is  now available on @Coursera! Training a model is only one step in building a working AI system. These courses teach you how to navigate some key deployment scenarios. Enroll here: https://t.co/iVWrTi8QGD https://t.co/ifzwCpFbUK

I‚Äôm excited about the opening of @Stanford‚Äôs new hospital! In addition to improving patient care, hopefully will also be a new platform for many AI and healthcare innovations. Congrats to all that made this possible! @DEntwistleSHC https://t.co/tPJk4UoG9K

Since announcing Pie & AI in March, we‚Äôve held events in 16 cities around the world. Let's keep the momentum going! If you want to host an event with us and support your local community of deep learners, you can apply at https://t.co/VOSBQedKXE. https://t.co/mtOGlqH9hy

It‚Äôs Halloween, but we don‚Äôt have to succumb to our fears, especially around the future of AI. If you want to know how scared you should or shouldn‚Äôt be, you can read our take on 6 AI fears in the Halloween special edition of The Batch! https://t.co/ya1Wuufk28 https://t.co/QowNCODZYy

I recently reread Fred Brooks‚Äô classic essay ‚ÄúNo Silver Bullet,‚Äù as I‚Äôve been thinking about how to reduce the essential complexity of building ML systems. Shared some thoughts about it in The Batch this week, which you can read here: https://t.co/49m6xKfFgv

Announcing our first international office in Medellin, Colombia! Landing AI, https://t.co/Ryb1M38abX and AI Fund have teams there. AI needs to expand beyond a small handful of hubs like Silicon Valley and Beijing, and I‚Äôm bullish about Latin America. https://t.co/47F1ilF5Ab

Introducing The Batch, a new weekly newsletter from @deeplearningai_! AI is growing so fast that it‚Äôs hard to know what news is useful or valuable. Subscribe to The Batch for a curated report on the latest AI research and industry-shaping events: https://t.co/UtwpmsIPub

Congratulations to Martial Hebert on becoming CMU's new Dean of CS! I have fond memories of working with him, @SebastianThrun, and others long ago on a DARPA project using helicopters+ground robots to build 3D maps. Looking forward to more great things from @SCSatCMU!

The final course of the https://t.co/Ryb1M38abX TensorFlow Specialization is now available on Coursera! You‚Äôll learn how to build time series models, and at the end you‚Äôll train a deep neural network on real-world data to predict sunspot activity: https://t.co/Pc6rnprpeI https://t.co/iv6CqlMZhm

We've used reinforcement learning from human feedback to train language models for summarization. The resulting models produce better summaries than 10x larger models trained only with supervised learning: https://t.co/Sk31d1CnTu
Applications are now open for our Fall 2020 Scholars program, which supports underrepresented groups in STEM to study deep learning full-time for 6 months. Apply here: https://t.co/pIvZkJXO6p

We recognize these issues are complex; as an industry we need to work together to improve the way we tackle them. New projects that expand OpenAI‚Äôs work in these critical areas are underway, building on existing work in the field. Research & product outputs to come. 8/8

We‚Äôre deploying a content filtration system as a starting point to allow a developer to control what content can be returned. Technology alone won't be the answer; we're working with users and our Academic Access partners for a more comprehensive approach. 7/8

Before applications go live, they‚Äôre also subject to a review with the OpenAI team. Our technical enforcement is catching up to our policies, and the process is improving. We still have many policies to create. 6/8
As we gain more experience operating the API in practice we expect to expand and refine these categories. We‚Äôre actively enforcing our terms of use. 5/8

We‚Äôve shared API Usage Guidelines w/ users that include heuristics for safely developing applications. We do not support use cases which may cause physical or mental harm, including but not limited to harassment, intentional deception, radicalization, astroturfing, or spam. 4/8

Generative models can display both overt and diffuse harmful outputs, such as racist, sexist, or otherwise pernicious language. This is an industry-wide issue, making it easy for individual organizations to abdicate or defer responsibility. OpenAI will not. 3/8

We rolled out limited access to the API via a private beta, which is a way for us to understand the challenges of deploying open-ended generative models in the real world, but with mechanisms in place for safety. 2/8

Last month we released an API for developers to build on top of our latest technology: https://t.co/4BaTBWzRtQ. There‚Äôs been a lot of enthusiasm, but a great deal needs to be figured out as we scale up access. Here's how we're thinking about it. 1/8

Over the past 5 months our 3rd class of Scholars researched how GPT-2 represents grammar, measured the interpretability of models trained on Coinrun, predicted epileptic seizures using brain recordings and more: https://t.co/XmKfSgdLB1
We're proud to support the National Research Cloud initiative to direct more computation to academia: https://t.co/gybBQ6tqkZ

We're releasing an API for accessing new AI models developed by OpenAI. You can "program" the API in natural language with just a few examples of your task. See how companies are using the API today, or join our waitlist: https://t.co/SvTgaFuTzN https://t.co/uoeeuqpDWR

We're co-organizing two NeurIPS 2020 competitions using Procgen Benchmark and MineRL. We rely heavily on these environments internally for RL research, and we look forward to seeing the progress the community makes in these challenging competitions. https://t.co/ROe3zGAbwC

It‚Äôs not enough for a company to be non-racist or to tweet Black Lives Matter. We want to be actively anti-racist, and to do that we need to make proactive corrections when it comes to sharing space and opportunity. We‚Äôre committed to doing the work. (4/4)

At OpenAI our aim is to ensure that advanced AI systems of the future are built to benefit everyone. That means we need to work harder to diversify our employees too. We‚Äôve not done a good enough job on this to date. (3/4)

We‚Äôre significantly expanding the number of Scholars, and we‚Äôd be excited if all additional slots go to members of the Black community, whom we will heavily recruit. We‚Äôll share details in the coming weeks for this next class of Scholars. (2/4)

We‚Äôve been talking at OpenAI about what we can do to help Black equity. We‚Äôre committing $1M to this cause via direct donations and expanding our Scholars program, which provides educational resources and mentoring to underrepresented groups in AI. (1/4)

A surprising deep learning mystery:

Contrary to conventional wisdom, performance of unregularized CNNs, ResNets, and transformers is non-monotonic: improves, then gets worse, then improves again with increasing model size, data size, or training time.

We've analyzed compute used in major AI results for the past decades and identified two eras in AI:

We‚Äôre all used to robots that fail when their environment changes unpredictably. Our robotic system is adaptable enough to handle unexpected situations not seen during training, such as being prodded by a stuffed giraffe: https://t.co/wBoh1nt9Kv

@FelixHill84 @mcxfrank Yeah, I think that is sadly a common experience when submitting cogsci work to NeurIPS. I do think it points to there being a weaker connection between the fields in that not as many ML folks appreciate the value of those types of papers as in previous decades

@FelixHill84 @rtk254 Oh, another big one coming from the compsci side is connections with HCI. I don't know enough about the historical trends in all of these fields though to know exactly how to fit them in üòï
@FelixHill84 ...but my sense is the *proportion* of cogsci work at NeurIPS has gone way down. Would be interesting to actually quantify this and see if it's true though.

@FelixHill84 I know there is a sense amongst some senior cogsci researchers that it's really hard to publish cognitive modeling work at NeurIPS these days. Whereas 10+ years ago was much easier. Of course, it's hard in general to publish at NeurIPS these days...

@FelixHill84 @rtk254 But I agree, even at the time (& since) there were other threads feeding into AI & CogSci, e.g. one thing that's underrepresented in the chart is influence from sociology and anthropology. Happy to update it to reflect other trends if you want to suggest edits! üôÇ

If you take this to an extreme, that means the "O" notation for computational complexity that's usually used in CS for algorithm complexity becomes (even) less relevant, and algorithms and data structures that are optimum might change drastically.

Interesting trend made very explicit in https://t.co/Tg0ZzAXLVd "Efficiently Searching In-Memory Sorted Arrays". Memory access is getting much slower compared to computation, so complexity in terms of compute is not the most relevant measure of algorithm runtime any more.

Despite the title, I think there are many important use-cases, in particular if you have a lot of data. I just really want to encourage people to start simple and critically evaluate when to take on more complex technology or algorithms and what the trade-offs are.

@code_star in our recent paper it was the classic ResNet-34: https://t.co/lt4eHQYxVc But yeah the focus wasn't on ResNet. Could have used any other architecture but ResNet works quite well out of the box with Adam, doesn't take too long to train, and fits comfortably into GPU memory

@denfromufa i don't think it is strictly a constant ~10. I think the approach is to decrease the learning rate whenever the loss stops shrinking for a couple of epochs. I actually like this approach, keeps you from decaying the learning rate too much & too early

@NirantK @spacy_io If you really want to, you can have spacy.load("en") back by creating a symlink in your working dir. Shortcut to find path:

from spacy.util import get_package_path, get_package_version

pkg = "en_core_web_sm"
path = get_package_path(pkg) / f"{pkg}-{get_package_version(pkg)}"

@NirantK @spacy_io Creating symlinks in arbitrary package directories is just too "magical" with too many side-effects, sorry! Plus, we want to avoid the idea of "the" English model ‚Äì there can be many pipelines & they're data packages, not library components. Explicit names makes this more clear.

Instead, choose a product that helps you make decisions, be more productive or automate your work by putting a model's predictions *into context*. Choose a product that's transparent & that you can work *with* ‚Äì not one that claims to do all the work for you, no questions asked.

Addition: Choose tools over "solutions" & be wary of vendors who promise to "solve" your business problem at the click of a button. If what you're doing is at all valuable, you don't want to only be paying for access to a black-box model you can't control.

This is a great thread and applies to evaluating ML claims by vendors in most industries, IMO.

Ask about system & data, question the use of ML vs. other approaches & don't get intimidated by obfuscation. If they claim "0 false positives/negatives", end the call üôÖ‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è

@pythiccoder @spacy_io @PyTorchLightnin No, but it should be pretty easy to wrap, it's just a layer on top of PyTorch, right? All spaCy does is wrap the PT model with Thinc's PyTorchWrapper. That's also how the transformers support works: it's a pipeline component that holds a wrapped model. https://t.co/uuobuzmqIO

nlp.analyze_pipes statically analyzes the current components in the pipeline and shows a summary of the attributes they assign and require, plus any potential conflicts. This helps you catch bugs before running your pipeline üöÄ

üìñ https://t.co/JLY5EelDhs https://t.co/bRH8luuYTP

Token.morph gives you easy access to a token's morphological analysis, either as a single FEATS string or by field.

üìñ https://t.co/uXlYQDvF17 https://t.co/vTxpWqVVWb

A Doc object can now be initialized with various linguistic annotations and token-based tags, making it easy to convert your data to spaCy's data structures. This is especially useful now that Doc objects are also used as training data!

üìñ https://t.co/5E9Sq6415i https://t.co/DKOAvIPyDl

Matcher.add now supports greedy matches! The value of the greedy attribute can either be "FIRST" or "LONGEST".

Sweet because: These are signs that NeurIPS is maturing. @_KarenHao wrote an article about the community growing up: https://t.co/27QvaQQkB8 We‚Äôre getting better at diversity/inclusion and taking responsibility for our actions, though there‚Äôs still room to grow.

Bayesian methods and causality got a lot of buzz. I was excited about progress in self-supervised learning, while others were excited about federated learning, or using DL to predict biological sequences. Fascinating areas, but the AI community no longer marches in one direction.
The community has grown so much that we no longer coalesce around a small handful of ideas. People now specialize more in verticals, and I felt less of the ‚Äúcore‚Äù coming together, which I miss.
Reflecting on #NeurIPS2019. Great meeting as usual, but the AI community is maturing, which felt bittersweet. Bitter because:

We recognize these issues are complex; as an industry we need to work together to improve the way we tackle them. New projects that expand OpenAI‚Äôs work in these critical areas are underway, building on existing work in the field. Research & product outputs to come. 8/8

We‚Äôre deploying a content filtration system as a starting point to allow a developer to control what content can be returned. Technology alone won't be the answer; we're working with users and our Academic Access partners for a more comprehensive approach. 7/8

Before applications go live, they‚Äôre also subject to a review with the OpenAI team. Our technical enforcement is catching up to our policies, and the process is improving. We still have many policies to create. 6/8
As we gain more experience operating the API in practice we expect to expand and refine these categories. We‚Äôre actively enforcing our terms of use. 5/8

We‚Äôve shared API Usage Guidelines w/ users that include heuristics for safely developing applications. We do not support use cases which may cause physical or mental harm, including but not limited to harassment, intentional deception, radicalization, astroturfing, or spam. 4/8

Generative models can display both overt and diffuse harmful outputs, such as racist, sexist, or otherwise pernicious language. This is an industry-wide issue, making it easy for individual organizations to abdicate or defer responsibility. OpenAI will not. 3/8

We rolled out limited access to the API via a private beta, which is a way for us to understand the challenges of deploying open-ended generative models in the real world, but with mechanisms in place for safety. 2/8

Last month we released an API for developers to build on top of our latest technology: https://t.co/4BaTBWzRtQ. There‚Äôs been a lot of enthusiasm, but a great deal needs to be figured out as we scale up access. Here's how we're thinking about it. 1/8

It‚Äôs not enough for a company to be non-racist or to tweet Black Lives Matter. We want to be actively anti-racist, and to do that we need to make proactive corrections when it comes to sharing space and opportunity. We‚Äôre committed to doing the work. (4/4)

At OpenAI our aim is to ensure that advanced AI systems of the future are built to benefit everyone. That means we need to work harder to diversify our employees too. We‚Äôve not done a good enough job on this to date. (3/4)

We‚Äôre significantly expanding the number of Scholars, and we‚Äôd be excited if all additional slots go to members of the Black community, whom we will heavily recruit. We‚Äôll share details in the coming weeks for this next class of Scholars. (2/4)

We‚Äôve been talking at OpenAI about what we can do to help Black equity. We‚Äôre committing $1M to this cause via direct donations and expanding our Scholars program, which provides educational resources and mentoring to underrepresented groups in AI. (1/4)

A surprising deep learning mystery:

Contrary to conventional wisdom, performance of unregularized CNNs, ResNets, and transformers is non-monotonic: improves, then gets worse, then improves again with increasing model size, data size, or training time.

https://t.co/3PwNElyNC8 https://t.co/Zdox9dbIBv

We've analyzed compute used in major AI results for the past decades and identified two eras in AI:

1) Prior to 2012 - AI results closely tracked Moore's Law, w/ compute doubling every two years.

Human hands let us solve a wide variety of tasks. Even so, solving a Rubik's Cube one-handed isn't easy for humans. We're excited to continue to develop new AI technology and ultimately ensure that these systems benefit all of humanity. https://t.co/0ntSeJ5ueG
"Solving the Rubik's Cube with a Robot Hand" took many human hands over the past 2.5 years ‚Äî meet our Robotics team! (PS they're hiring: https://t.co/gSCOW9bguI!) https://t.co/jeCUEDtYY3

We‚Äôre all used to robots that fail when their environment changes unpredictably. Our robotic system is adaptable enough to handle unexpected situations not seen during training, such as being prodded by a stuffed giraffe: https://t.co/wBoh1nt9Kv

We've trained an AI system to solve the Rubik's Cube with a human-like robot hand.

This is an unprecedented level of dexterity for a robot, and is hard even for humans to do.

The system trains in an imperfect simulation and quickly adapts to reality: https://t.co/O04izt3KvO https://t.co/8lGhU2pPck

Now accepting applications for our 3rd class of OpenAI Scholars: a 4 month full-time program for individuals from underrepresented groups to study deep learning and produce an open-source project. Mentors include @mcleavey, @karlcobbe, @AlecRad: https://t.co/Xj5qVLi1ph

Wondering why the hiders did not cage in the seekers instead of building their own fort? In one environment variant where hiders have to protect glowing orbs, that's exactly what they learned to do! https://t.co/yifS7rI4eR

We've fine-tuned GPT-2 using human feedback for tasks such as summarizing articles, matching the preferences of human labelers (if not always our own). We're hoping this brings safety methods closer to machines learning values by talking with humans. https://t.co/ok9jeMP5zj
And seekers learn that if they run at a wall with a ramp at the right angle, they can launch themselves upward. https://t.co/SJv9SzctEp

Unexpected and surprising behaviors included box surfing, where seekers learn to bring a box to a locked ramp in order to jump on top of the box and then ‚Äúsurf‚Äù it to the hider‚Äôs shelter. https://t.co/v0kGfCYZna

We've observed AIs discovering complex tool use while competing in a simple game of hide-and-seek. They develop a series of six distinct strategies and counterstrategies, ultimately using tools in the environment to break our simulated physics: https://t.co/2lbOxo19rL

@FelixHill84 @mcxfrank Yeah, I think that is sadly a common experience when submitting cogsci work to NeurIPS. I do think it points to there being a weaker connection between the fields in that not as many ML folks appreciate the value of those types of papers as in previous decades

@FelixHill84 ...but my sense is the *proportion* of cogsci work at NeurIPS has gone way down. Would be interesting to actually quantify this and see if it's true though.

@FelixHill84 I know there is a sense amongst some senior cogsci researchers that it's really hard to publish cognitive modeling work at NeurIPS these days. Whereas 10+ years ago was much easier. Of course, it's hard in general to publish at NeurIPS these days...

@FelixHill84 @rtk254 But I agree, even at the time (& since) there were other threads feeding into AI & CogSci, e.g. one thing that's underrepresented in the chart is influence from sociology and anthropology. Happy to update it to reflect other trends if you want to suggest edits! üôÇ

@FelixHill84 @rtk254 Yes, they are supposed to be historic trends, thanks @rtk254 ! If anything, I think the state of AI and CogSci as they were defined at the 1956 confs were a reaction *against* logic and behaviorism as they had failed to provide a satisfactory theory of behavior

These tasks are very challenging due to their large action spaces, and in the case of Marble Run, a sparse and complex reward function. We hope that these tasks will serve as an interesting testbed for developing more sophisticated and flexible object-oriented agents! https://t.co/UrxD40lYyz

The Construction Tasks involve stacking blocks around obstacles to achieve various goals, such as reaching a point in the sky or to get a marble to roll into a goal. More details can be found in https://t.co/iEU0rIYkIm and https://t.co/zjAmrAo3OZ. https://t.co/xoKUVUDtK1

If you take this to an extreme, that means the "O" notation for computational complexity that's usually used in CS for algorithm complexity becomes (even) less relevant, and algorithms and data structures that are optimum might change drastically.

Interesting trend made very explicit in https://t.co/Tg0ZzAXLVd "Efficiently Searching In-Memory Sorted Arrays". Memory access is getting much slower compared to computation, so complexity in terms of compute is not the most relevant measure of algorithm runtime any more.

Despite the title, I think there are many important use-cases, in particular if you have a lot of data. I just really want to encourage people to start simple and critically evaluate when to take on more complex technology or algorithms and what the trade-offs are.

@joelgrus I find "from . import utils" makes it more obvious where something came from than "from https://t.co/1HHDo9lZyw.the.current.module import utils", in particular if you also have "from https://t.co/1HHDo9lZyw.the.other.module import utils".

TIL that there's very different stances of absolute vs relative imports within packages. sklearn uses all relative imports, pandas uses all absolute (from what I can tell). The most tangible thing discussing this I found was https://t.co/2x19FWSghy Any thoughts on best practices?

@afvantol @phi_max I think PyTorch is easier to use for research (because more flexible than TensorFlow's Keras main API and requires less hacking) but TensorFlow is easier to use for standard implementations & applications (because of the boilerplate that the Keras API takes away)

@code_star in our recent paper it was the classic ResNet-34: https://t.co/lt4eHQYxVc But yeah the focus wasn't on ResNet. Could have used any other architecture but ResNet works quite well out of the box with Adam, doesn't take too long to train, and fits comfortably into GPU memory

@denfromufa i don't think it is strictly a constant ~10. I think the approach is to decrease the learning rate whenever the loss stops shrinking for a couple of epochs. I actually like this approach, keeps you from decaying the learning rate too much & too early

@NirantK @spacy_io If you really want to, you can have spacy.load("en") back by creating a symlink in your working dir. Shortcut to find path:

from spacy.util import get_package_path, get_package_version

pkg = "en_core_web_sm"
path = get_package_path(pkg) / f"{pkg}-{get_package_version(pkg)}"

@NirantK @spacy_io Creating symlinks in arbitrary package directories is just too "magical" with too many side-effects, sorry! Plus, we want to avoid the idea of "the" English model ‚Äì there can be many pipelines & they're data packages, not library components. Explicit names makes this more clear.

Instead, choose a product that helps you make decisions, be more productive or automate your work by putting a model's predictions *into context*. Choose a product that's transparent & that you can work *with* ‚Äì not one that claims to do all the work for you, no questions asked.

Addition: Choose tools over "solutions" & be wary of vendors who promise to "solve" your business problem at the click of a button. If what you're doing is at all valuable, you don't want to only be paying for access to a black-box model you can't control.

This is a great thread and applies to evaluating ML claims by vendors in most industries, IMO.

Ask about system & data, question the use of ML vs. other approaches & don't get intimidated by obfuscation. If they claim "0 false positives/negatives", end the call üôÖ‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è

It helps you avoid bugs, keeps the config reproducible between runs and prevents unexpected results caused by hidden defaults somewhere in your components. 

You can read more about @spacy_io v3's config system here: https://t.co/5k5t82AhsC

The type-based validation and auto-filling works for all kinds of functions:

‚ñ™Ô∏è layers and model architectures
‚ñ™Ô∏è data readers and batchers
‚ñ™Ô∏è schedules and optimizers
‚ñ™Ô∏è pipeline components
‚ñ™Ô∏è any other callbacks

With the data model based on function arguments, we can provide another cool feature: auto-filling! 

If functions define defaults, we fill in the blanks in your config. `init fill-config` does this for you & can even show a pretty visual diff.

üìñ Docs: https://t.co/2OVYwC8MwM https://t.co/KLYwCQg5WM

To do this, we create a Pydantic model on the fly when we resolve the config:

1Ô∏è‚É£ inspect the function arguments, defaults and types
2Ô∏è‚É£ create a dynamic model
3Ô∏è‚É£ call model on data from config
4Ô∏è‚É£ handle validation errors https://t.co/qqOjrC9eK4

spaCy's config system takes this one step further: your config can include references to registered functions that are called when the config is resolved. If the registered functions provide type hints for their parameters, we also want to validate the arguments against them. https://t.co/QVHxyBPMnV

So what is Pydantic doing under the hood? 

When you're training models, you're passing a lot of settings all the way through your application. If something is wrong, we want to exit early & tell you what the problem is. So in the simplest case we can type the top-level settings: https://t.co/qzRR94kdPD

Pydantic provided so much value that we adopted it as a dependency of both Thinc and @spacy_io üíï And a new dependency is always a pretty big deal: in fact, spaCy v3 only has 5 real dependencies that are not maintained by us: numpy, requests, tqdm, pytokenizations and pydantic.

Pydantic lets you use basic standard library types like str or bool but it also includes various custom types like FilePath, AnyUrl or PositiveFloat. You can implement fully custom validation logic, and even export your data models to JSON schemas.

https://t.co/l3xv4T28XZ

I was first introduced to Pydantic by @tiangolo & FastAPI. The idea is pretty simple: you declare a data model, add type hints & the data will be converted to the specified types if possible. If not, you'll see a validation error that points out the field, value & expected type. https://t.co/ztOCPilHcN

One of the most significant changes in @spacy_io v3 is the new config system for defining & training pipelines.

Validation is crucial here, but how does it work? A key part is Pydantic by @samuel_colvin: https://t.co/p2nMltDvTj

Here's how it looks under the hood (thread) üëá https://t.co/Hnc4HmAVvr

@evanmiltenburg I guess it's a bit like a live concert, really üòÖ

(Although that metaphor falls apart immediately because I'd probably watch a low-res live video of my fav band performing but not a low-res Zoom call of my fav speaker redoing my fav talk by them üòÇ Or watch them live 15+ times.)

@evanmiltenburg I guess it's the experience of watching someone live on stage, speaking to an audience, in the context of an event in a certain place & interacting with ppl in person. A prerecorded video or low-res Zoom call couldn't replace that. So that's what I'm getting out of an IRL conf.

@evanmiltenburg Well, there's definitely no shortage of videos I want to record ‚Äì but when I do get around to recording, I might as well do it properly, exactly how I want, and upload the result to YouTube so everyone can watch it, rather than just submitting the video to some online conference.

@evanmiltenburg Yeah, it's kinda what I've been doing (declining invitations), but it still feels weird to tell a conference: here's a YT link, you can stream that if you want? üòÖ It's the same experience & objectively better, but I'm thinking, wait, that's not the point of a conference, is it?

@fishnets88 Good point, I think what you describe here goes more in the direction of educational live coding streams, which was already a very popular format pre-Corona because it just adds a lot of value and works for people (and sometimes can't even be replicated very well in real life!).

@ichderfisch That's an interesting perspective, I hadn't thought of it that way! 

I guess this could be similar for people who attend conferences during (some) of their work hours? Watching industry conf videos: ‚úÖ by company. Watching random YT videos employee selected themselves: tricky.
@wellytambunan Thank you! üòä

@gyrodiot Yes, I think a Q&A can definitely add value that you couldn't get from watching a video! Recorded panels can work too ‚Äì often better than IRL panels IMO if they have a podcast-y vibe.

(But would people show up just to watch a YT video together? Maybe if it's followed by a Q&A?)

I don't have a good answer for this ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è atm I'm just limiting my participation in online stuff. It's clear that there's a lot of value in a real life confs that most online versions don't capture ‚Äì and a lot of value in online content, which can be async (!) & is more accessible.

I put a lot of work into my talks & writing a new talk takes time. If I have the choice between submitting it to an arbitrary online conference or uploading it to YouTube where everyone can watch it, I'll always choose YT. That's not a conf's fault ‚Äì it's just the best trade-off.

For example, at a real life conf, I might do this talk again: https://t.co/9xOFR9EIHf

But I already have a good, professionally recorded version of it. There's no real value in making people watch a worse version of it "live" when they could just watch the other video instead.

How are others dealing w/ the dilemma of giving similar talks at online conferences? ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è

Like, why make ppl watch a crappy live talk if they could watch a better video I already have? I'm not gonna re-record. But where's the value in a conf that just streams YT videos? (thread)
